definition: Former Han dynasty school of Confucian scholars
study of the Confucian classics
Confucianism
Mr Gongyang's Annals or commentary on 春秋[Chun1 qiu1], early history, probably written during Han dynasty, same as 公羊傳|公羊传[Gong1 yang2 Zhuan4]
Confucian school, founded by Confucius 孔子[Kong3 zi3] (551-479 BC) and Mencius 孟子[Meng4 zi3] (c. 372-c. 289 BC)
Dong Zhongshu (179-104 BC), philosopher influential in establishing Confucianism as the established system of values of former Han dynasty
historiography

Legalist School of the Warring States Period (475-221 BC) founded by Han Fei 韓非|韩非[Han2 Fei1] and Li Si 李斯[Li3 Si1], later adopted by Shang Yang 商鞅[Shang1 Yang1] whose reforms helped establish the supremacy of the Qin Dynasty 秦代[Qin1 dai4] (221-207 BC)
school of thought
Liu Shipei (1884-1919), Chinese anarchist and revolutionary activist
dismiss the hundred schools, revere only the Confucians (slogan of the Former Han dynasty)
Western learning (intellectual movement in the late Qing)/also called 洋務運動|洋务运动
intellectual history
Confucian
New Confucianism, a social and political movement founded in 1920s China that combines aspects of Western and Eastern philosophy/see also 當代新儒家|当代新儒家[Dang1 dai4 Xin1 Ru2 jia1]
divination combined with mystical Confucian philosopy, prevalent during the Eastern Han Dynasty (25-220)
